question: The module explains the 3 characteristics of Big Data, namely Variety, Velocity and Volume. Name and explain the other 2Vs that have been explained in the module.

question: The module explains the 3 characteristics of Big Data, namely Variety, Velocity and Volume. Name and explain the other 2Vs that have been explained in the module.
ground_truth: The other two Vs are: 1. Veracity: Refers to the quality and accuracy of data. In large data sets, there is often incomplete, inaccurate, or irrelevant data, which can disrupt the analysis process if not handled properly. 2. Value: Refers to the value or information that can be obtained from Big Data processing. Having large volumes of data with high velocity, variety, and veracity is useless without the ability to convert it into business value or useful knowledge.
answer: Apart from the 3V, namely Variety, Velocity, and Volume, the other 2V which are characteristics of Big Data are: Veracity. Veracity or truth is a characteristic of Big Data which means that Big Data has a certain degree of reliability of the data. Because the majority of data is unstructured and irrelevant, Big Data needs an alternative way to filter out inappropriate data, or translate it if necessary when needed. In this case, Big Data has vulnerabilities in terms of accuracy and validity so it requires depth to analyze Big Data in order to produce the right decisions. Thus, Big Data must reach a certain degree of reliability so that the existing data is valid for use in its implementation. Value. Value includes not only the amount of data in Big Data that is stored and processed, but also includes the amount of valuable, true and valid data that must be stored, processed and analyzed in its implementation. Thus, Big Data has very high value if it is processed in an appropriate way.

question: The module explains the 3 characteristics of Big Data, namely Variety, Velocity and Volume. Name and explain the other 2Vs that have been explained in the module.
ground_truth: The other two Vs are: 1. Veracity: Refers to the quality and accuracy of data. In large data sets, there is often incomplete, inaccurate, or irrelevant data, which can disrupt the analysis process if not handled properly. 2. Value: Refers to the value or information that can be obtained from Big Data processing. Having large volumes of data with high velocity, variety, and veracity is useless without the ability to convert it into business value or useful knowledge.
answer: VERACITY Big data has vulnerabilities in terms of accuracy and validity so it requires depth to analyze big data in order to produce the right decisions. The character of veracity refers to how accurate and trustworthy the data is. VALUE Value means that big data has a very high value if it is processed in an appropriate way or it can also be said how valuable or meaningful the data is. For example, employee biodata of a company selling food raw materials will not be of value for predictive analysis of raw material sales to customers. The data may be unimportant and of no value for one thing, but it can be very important and very valuable for another thing. Data that has no value in any part will not be filtered in the Big Data analysis application system.

Sentiment analysis can be used to determine public sentiment, especially Twitter and Facebook netizens, towards a candidate in an election or regional election. The aim is to help people determine the sentiment contained in comments on social media Twitter and Facebook. The first step that must be taken is to collect the necessary data, namely comments from people who use social media regarding candidates in elections or regional elections. Sources of research data can come from social media Twitter and Facebook. Next, the text preprocessing stage will be carried out. For text obtained from public comments, a process of sentence selection, sentence cleaning, sentence stemming and sentence normalization will be carried out. After the text has been processed and has become clean text, it will proceed to the classification process stage. In the classification process, the Nave Bayes Classifier method can be used to determine the sentiment of an opinion sentence. The final stage is to evaluate the performance of Accuracy, Precision, Recall and Error using the Confusion Matrix method. - Marketing a. Telecommunications companies leverage big data analysis to prevent customer churn. Apart from that, big data is also used to plan the best way to optimize wireless networks, both new and existing, so that product marketing can run smoothly. b. Marketing uses big data to carry out sentiment analysis to determine the level of customer satisfaction with the products and services being marketed, so that more effective marketing tricks can be designed and attract the interest of many customers. c. Retail companies can use information from social media such as Facebook, Twitter, Google which is stored using big data technology, which is then used to analyze customer behavior and perceptions of a company's product or brand. - Education Data analysis through big data allows teachers or consultants to provide advice on very specific career directions to students. A startup in Santa Monica, 12Twenty offers solutions in service management or career information centers for educational institutions, students, and entrepreneurs. 12Twenty also provides a range of products such as a career recommendation platform, more effective management of employment processes, giving students a better understanding of the hiring cycle, and helping employers find candidates according to their desires and expectations. Apart from that, 12Twenty uses big data to give students access to salary information and a list of interview questions through a database so that after graduation students can prepare optimally when there is an interview call. - Corporate Health can conduct clinical trials, using Big Data and predictive analysis. question: Give examples of Big Data implementation in your respective fields
ground_truth: Here are some examples of Big Data implementation in various fields: 1. Social Media Sentiment Analysis: Companies can use Big Data to analyze sentiment on social media towards their brand, product or service. By monitoring millions of tweets, Facebook posts, and other online reviews, they can understand customer views in real-time, identify trends, and respond quickly to changing perceptions or emerging issues. 2. Health Data Processing: In the health sector, Big Data is used to analyze clinical, genomic and other patient data to discover patterns, trends, and associations that can assist in disease diagnosis, drug development, and more effective and personalized treatment planning. 3. Supply Chain Optimization: Companies operating in the manufacturing or retail industry use Big Data to optimize their supply chains. By analyzing data related to customer demand, inventory, and production processes, they can identify areas where efficiency can be improved, reduce costs, and increase customer satisfaction by ensuring the right product is available at the right time.
answer: 1. UNITEDHEALTHCARE: FRAUD, WASTE, AND ABUSE Currently at least 10 of Health insurance payments are related to fraudulent claims. Worldwide this case is estimated to be worth billions of dollars. False claims are not a new problem, but the complexity of insurance fraud appears to be increasing exponentially making it difficult for health insurance companies to deal with it. UnitedHealthCare is an insurance company that provides health benefits and services to nearly 51 million people. This company collaborates with more than 850,000 health workers and around 6,100 hospitals throughout the country. Payment Integrity group's payment integrity division has a duty to ensure that claims are paid correctly and on time. Previously, their approach to managing more than one million claims per day, around 10 TB of data per day, was ad hoc, heavily regulated, and hampered by fragmented data. The solution taken by UnitedHealthCare is a dual mode approach, which focuses on allocating savings while implementing innovation to continue to utilize the latest technology. 2. HADOOP TECHNOLOGY FOR MONITORING THE VITAL CONDITION OF PATIENTS Hadoop is a Java-based open source framework or platform under the Apache license to support applications that run on Big Data. Several hospitals around the world have used Hadoop to help their staff work efficiently with Big Data. Without Hadoop, it would be nearly impossible for most healthcare systems to analyze unstructured data. Children's Healthcare of Atlanta uses sensors at the patient's bedside to track the patient's vital conditions such as heart rate, breathing and blood pressure. This sensor can produce very large amounts of data and the system is not able to process this data because storing the data requires large amounts of storage and the costs are large. even though this hospital needs to store vital data for analysis. If there is a change in pattern, there needs to be notification to the team of doctors and staff. 3. VALENCE HEALTH: IMPROVING SERVICE QUALITY AND REIMBURSEMENTS Valence health uses Hadoop to build a data lake which is the main storage of company data. Valence processes 3000 inbound data feeds with 45 types of data every day. This critical data includes lab test results, medical record data, doctor's prescriptions, immunizations, medications, claims and payments, as well as claims from doctors and hospitals, which are used to inform decisions about increasing both income and reimbursement. The rapid growth in the number of clients and the associated increase in data volumes increasingly strain existing infrastructure

Data allows for more accurate inventory tracking, so supply disruptions do not occur and pharmacists can take advantage of bulk purchases and special price offers. Using data, pharmacists can make treatment recommendations based on elements such as diet, supplements, drug education and medication adherence.

answer: There are 5V characteristics of big data: volume, velocity, variety, veracity, value. VOLUME: Big data volume is very large so it requires a very large disk space. This means that data cannot be processed traditionally. VARIETY: Big data has characteristics that are not homogeneous, diverse, can be structured, unstructured, semi-structured and data also comes in various forms such as email, PDF, photos, audio, video, etc. VELOCITY: Big data has the characteristic of changing very quickly both in terms of variables and data types. This fast-changing data could mean that when the data is finished processing three hours later, this data will no longer be relevant and useless, so real-time data with fast processing will be more profitable in making better decisions. VERACITY: Big data is not always valid and accurate, so depth is needed in analyzing big data in order to produce the right decisions. VALUE: If it is like a pyramid, value is at the top. Big data has very high value if it can be processed and analyzed appropriately.

Variety: Describes the different types and sources of data available, including structured, unstructured, and semi-structured data. 4. Veracity: Relates to the quality and accuracy of data. 5. Value: Refers to the value or information that can be obtained from Big Data processing. These characteristics highlight the scale, complexity, and diversity of Big Data, which require specialized tools and techniques to manage and analyze.
answer: The characteristics of a data collection called big data are that it has 5 characteristics in the form of: 1. Variety Big Data variations refer to structured, unstructured and semi-structured data collected from various sources. Examples include emails, PDFs, photos, videos, audio, SM posts, and more. 2. Velocity Velocity or speed is the speed of data when created in real-time. Velocity broadly consists of rates of change, accumulating data coming in at varying rates, as well as bursts of activity. 3. Volume Volume is one of the characteristics of Big Data. We already know that Big Data denotes the huge volume of data generated every day from various sources such as social media platforms, business processes, machines, networks, human interactions, etc. 4. Veracity Big data has vulnerabilities in terms of accuracy so it requires depth to analyze big data in order to produce the right decisions. 5. Value Value means how valuable or meaningful the data is. The data may be unimportant and of no value for one thing, but it can be very important and very valuable for another thing.

Intended Use: Relational databases are designed for daily transactional and operational data (OLTP), while data warehouses are designed for data analysis and business reporting (OLAP). 2. Data Structure: Relational databases use a structured schema with tables, rows, and columns, whereas data warehouses use a format optimized for querying and analysis, often using a star schema or snow schema. 3. Optimization: Relational databases are optimized for speed and efficiency in processing small to medium data transactions in real-time, whereas data warehouses are optimized for big data processing and analysis, supporting complex and data-intensive read operations.
answer: 1. Relational Database The Relational Database Model presents data in two-dimensional tables, like a spreadsheet, only it is not presented in a table like a spreadsheet but uses a combination or joining of relational tables to produce a view or display results. 2. Data Warehouse Data Warehouse Model, also known as enterprise data warehouse is a system used for data reporting and analysis and is considered a core component of business intelligence.

question: What are the 3 differences between a relational database and a data warehouse?
ground_truth: The three main differences between a relational database and a data warehouse are: 1. Intended Use: Relational databases are designed for daily transactional and operational data (OLTP), while data warehouses are designed for data analysis and business reporting (OLAP). 2. Data Structure: Relational databases use a structured schema with tables, rows, and columns, whereas data warehouses use a format optimized for querying and analysis, often using a star schema or snow schema. 3. answer: A data warehouse is a broad scope of storage and processing of various data sources, not only relational databases, which are integrated and easy to display information in drilldown or rollup. In general, the data warehouse process is: OLTPETLdata warehousedata martanalysisreport The relational database that is commonly used is the OLTP online transaction process area with its characteristics: 1. relational database 2. Normalized database 3. Changeable 4. Realtime 5. large database 6. Can be Various Data Source flat file, DBMS etc. Meanwhile, data warehouse is the second stage, where data is no longer queried in large quantities and normalized, but data that has been aggregated according to reporting analysis needs and has been denormalized due to consideration of query speed. If the data has to be done qiery by carrying out a lot of JOIN processes like in an OLTP database then the process will be very heavy. Moreover, the OLTP data is very large. Then, a data warehouse is an aggregation of various different data sources.

question: What are the 3 differences between a relational database and a data warehouse?
ground_truth: The three main differences between a relational database and a data warehouse are: 1. Intended Use: Relational databases are designed for daily transactional and operational data (OLTP), while data warehouses are designed for data analysis and business reporting (OLAP). 2. Data Structure: Relational databases use a structured schema with tables, rows, and columns, whereas data warehouses use a format optimized for querying and analysis, often using a star schema or snow schema. 3. Optimization: Relational databases are optimized for speed and efficiency in processing small to medium data transactions in real-time, whereas data warehouses are optimized for big data processing and analysis, supporting complex and data-intensive read operations.
answer: A relational database is a collection of data items with predefined relationships. These various items are organized into a set of tables with columns and rows. Tables are used to store information about objects that will be represented in the database. Each column in a table contains a specific type of data and fields store the actual values ​​of attributes. Rows in a table represent a collection of related values ​​from a single object or entity. Each row in a table can be tagged with a unique identifier called a primary key, and rows between multiple tables can be made related to each other using foreign keys. This data can be accessed in various ways without reordering the database tables themselves. Database Warehouse is a database system commonly used for reporting and data analysis. This system is considered a core component of business intelligence. A Warehouse Database is a central, integrated repository of data from one or more different sources. The database also stores current and historical data in one place that is used to create analysis reports.

question: What are the 3 differences between a relational database and a data warehouse?
ground_truth: The three main differences between a relational database and a data warehouse are: 1. Intended Use: Relational databases are designed for daily transactional and operational data (OLTP), while data warehouses are designed for data analysis and business reporting (OLAP). 2. Data Structure: Relational databases use a structured schema with tables, rows, and columns, whereas data warehouses use a format optimized for querying and analysis, often using a star schema or snow schema. 3. Relational databases are designed to store data while data warehouses are designed to analyze data. A relational database is a data set with an application orientation while a data warehouse is a data set with a subject orientation. Relational databases use Online Transactional Processing OLTP while Data warehouses use Online Analytical Processing OLAP. Relational databases have more complex data because they tend to be normalized while data warehouses have less complex data because they are not normalized. ER modeling techniques are used to design relational databases while data modeling techniques are used to design data warehouses.

Data warehouse: Data warehouse organizes and processes large amounts of historical data and provides several facilities. Data warehouses also deal with various information obtained from several other organizations, which combine from various data storage places. This is because most of the data stored is historical data and only a little new data.

Intended Use: Relational databases are designed for daily transactional and operational data (OLTP), while data warehouses are designed for data analysis and business reporting (OLAP). 2. Data Structure: Relational databases use a structured schema with tables, rows, and columns, whereas data warehouses use a format optimized for querying and analysis, often using a star schema or snow schema. 3. Optimization: Relational databases are optimized for speed and efficiency in processing small to medium data transactions in real-time, whereas data warehouses are optimized for big data processing and analysis, supporting complex and data-intensive read operations.
answer: A relational database is a collection of data with predetermined relationships. These relationships are displayed in the form of a set of tables with columns and rows. Meanwhile, a data warehouse is a computer system that archives and analyzes organizational or company data. Typically contains historical data derived from transaction data, but may include data from other sources.

question: What are the 3 differences between a relational database and a data warehouse?
ground_truth: The three main differences between a relational database and a data warehouse are: 1. Intended Use: Relational databases are designed for daily transactional and operational data (OLTP), while data warehouses are designed for data analysis and business reporting (OLAP). 2. Data Structure: Relational databases use a structured schema with tables, rows, and columns, whereas data warehouses use a format optimized for querying and analysis, often using a star schema or snow schema. 3. Optimization: Relational databases are optimized for speed and efficiency in processing small to medium data transactions in real-time, whereas data warehouses are optimized for big data processing and analysis, supporting complex and data-intensive read operations.
answer: A relational database is a database that consists of many tables, where each table has its own function and use, and each table can be connected by relationships in primary key and foreign key fields. Examples include: Microsoft Access, SQL Server, MySQL, OpenOffice Base, and Oracle. Meanwhile, a data warehouse is a system consisting of several processes and databases that are used to provide data infrastructure for EIS and DSS. The Data Warehouse is organized by data subjects associated with the organization. For example: Customer, Claim, Shiftment, Product, Minimarket Center. Apart from that, relational databases organize and process data in detail so that they are easy to use in the decision making process. Meanwhile, the data warehouse organizes and processes large amounts of historical data and provides several facilities for calculating total sales and combining sales in each area, each month, and so on. Data warehouses store and process data according to different levels of granularity.

Data Structure: Relational databases use a structured schema with tables, rows, and columns, whereas data warehouses use a format optimized for querying and analysis, often using a star schema or snow schema. 3. Optimization: Relational databases are optimized for speed and efficiency in processing small to medium data transactions in real-time, whereas data warehouses are optimized for big data processing and analysis, supporting complex and data-intensive read operations.
answer: A warehouse is a broad scope of storage and processing from various data sources, not only relational databases, which are integrated and easy to display information in drilldown or rollup. The commonly used relational database is the OLTP online transaction process area. Meanwhile, the data warehouse is the second stage, where data is no longer queried in large quantities and normalized, but the data has been aggregated according to the needs of the analysis report and has been normalized.

question: What challenges exist when implementing Big Data?
ground_truth: When implementing Big Data, the following challenges exist: 1. Data Management and Storage 2. Data Processing and Analysis 3. Data Quality and Cleanliness 4. Data Security and Privacy 5. Data Integration 6. Skills Shortage 7. Infrastructure and Operational Costs 8. Scalability 9. Business Understanding 10. Regulations and Compliance
answer: Big Data technology is a relatively new and developing technology. Currently, the focus of Big Data development is still focused on analysis capacity and data storage because these two things are the most important factors in determining the level of effectiveness and success of the Big Data system. This has an impact on the lack of energy and capital used to develop data security, resulting in various cases of data breaches and information theft. Currently, hackers and Big Data security continue to be developed continuously to ensure that systems that use Big Data are safe from data breaches or other forms of information theft and of course this requires quite frequent design changes or code updates. Even though this process takes a lot of time and energy. In addition, along with the times and innovations in the implementation of new technology, the types of data become increasingly diverse, the size of available data will grow exponentially. Moreover, considering that big data management is much different from conventional relational databases, sorting the desired data from the incoming data set is quite difficult. Data Availability One of the keys to conducting Big Data analysis is of course data availability. Access to data, both old data and new data, can be an obstacle for Big Data, especially old data which is stored in different and varied forms, often in physical form. Access to new data also requires more effort because permits and licenses are required to legally access non-public data. Especially if there is sectoral ego between agencies as data owners. This is what service and information providers who implement Big Data analytics in Indonesia feel, that the data collection phase is the main challenge. In fact, in Indonesia, data for various types of needs is available and abundant, but the sources are scattered, so more effort is needed to obtain integrated data nationally. Data Privacy On the one hand, data transparency is needed, but on the other hand, privacy is a sensitive issue and is often compromised through technological advances. Privacy relates to a person's personal data that must be protected. Much of the data used as Big Data, which is obtained directly from consumers, is personal data and is very vulnerable to misuse by other parties. When just one data requires guaranteed security, then when there is integration of data from several sources, the level of security must be further increased. answer: There are four challenges in analyzing big data, namely data volume, data variety, data speed, and data correctness. First, as the name suggests, the size of big data is very large. Meanwhile, existing technology is not designed to process big data that has low locality or no locality, is dynamic, large in size, and cannot be loaded in memory. Therefore, in processing big data we have to return to statistical methods. Second, data has many variations and dimensions. In other words, data is diverse, heterogeneous, can be structured or unstructured. Then, speed is also a challenge. Data arrives continuously in the form of a data stream. Therefore, it is difficult to get useful information in real time and determine which data should be kept and which should be discarded. The final challenge is the correctness of the data. A lot of data changes all the time, so the truth of the data becomes uncertain.

With the emergence of big data, new technologies and companies, the big challenge faced by companies in big data analysis is to know which technology is most suitable for them without new problems and potential risks. -Storage and data quality. Popular data storage options such as data lakes warehouses are generally used to collect and store large amounts of unstructured and structured data in their native format. Missing data, inconsistent data, logic conflicts, and duplicate data all result in data quality challenges. -Data security and privacy. Big data also involves potential risks regarding data privacy and security. Big data tools are used for analysis and storage using different data sources. This ultimately leads to a high risk of data exposure and makes it vulnerable. Increasing amounts of data also raise privacy and security concerns.

Missing data, inconsistent data, logic conflicts, and duplicate data all result in data quality challenges. Data security and privacy. Big Data also involves potential risks regarding data privacy and security. Big Data tools are used for analysis and storage using different data sources. This ultimately leads to a high risk of data exposure and makes it vulnerable. Increasing amounts of data also raise privacy and security concerns.
